title: High Monocytes? 5 Ways to Balance Your Immune System - SelfDecode Labs
author: Joe Cohen; BS
description: Do you have high monocytes? Learn about ways to balance immune function & strategies associated with decreased monocytes here.
cleaned_text: largest of all white blood cells and play an important role in the defense against germs and in inflammation. What do high levels mean? What factors can decrease them? Learn more here. High Levels of Monocytes (Monocytosis) Monocytosis is a condition in which the number of monocytes circulating in the blood is increased to more than 0.8×109/L in adults. Conditions Associated with Monocytosis - Blood disorders (myelodysplastic disorder, acute monocytic, chronic Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphoma) [ [1](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/9107078), [3](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/3291931)] Infections disease) [ attack [ [4](https://selfhacked.com/blog/app/uploads/2017/12/U014528186.pdf), [15](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/11788214)] Appendicitis [ [16](http://www.scielo.br/scielo.php?pid=S0102-67202012000200005&script=sci_arttext&tlng=en)] - HIV infection [ - Depression [ [18](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/1613679)] - Childbirth [ [19](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/7261863), [20](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/3855436)] - Obesity [ [21](http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1550413114001636#)] - Severe pneumonia [ [22](https://www.researchgate.net/publication/41408038_Relative_lymphopenia_and_monocytosis_may_be_considered_as_a_surrogate_marker_of_pandemic_influenza_a_H1N1)] - Alcoholic liver disease [ [23](http://www.bloodjournal.org/content/122/21/4725?sso-checked=true)] Causes shown here are commonly associated with this symptom. Work with your doctor or other health care professional for an accurate diagnosis. Symptoms and Causes Monocytosis most commonly occurs during and after chronic inflammation or infection [ [24](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23228954)]. However, several other conditions can also be associated with monocytosis, such as heart disease, depression, diabetes, and obesity [ [25](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5515748/), [ 26](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4203415/), [ 27](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/25319334)]. The conditions most commonly associated with high monocyte levels are: - Chronic (long-term) inflammation [ [24](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23228954)] - Infections, such as tuberculosis, malaria, and syphilis [ [28](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/11837465), [29](https://www.ajol.info/index.php/njcp/article/view/11121), [30](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/879114)] High monocyte levels may also be linked to: - Autoimmune diseases, such as lupus, rheumatoid arthritis, and IBD [ [12](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/835948), [10](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/2981945), [11](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC1146286/)] such as leukemia, and juvenile myelomonocytic leukemia [ [31](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3459633/), [32](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3710560/)] - Cancer [ [33](https://academic.oup.com/jnci/article/63/3/587/1056406)] - Depression [ [18](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/1613679)] - Obesity [ [34](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/24807222)] Few symptoms are considered to be caused by monocytosis itself. Instead, according to many researchers, symptoms arise from the diseases associated with monocytosis [ [26](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4203415/)]. These symptoms include: How Are High Monocytes Linked to Health? 1) Atherosclerosis Monocytes and macrophages are involved in the development and worsening of atherosclerosis (hardening of the arteries) that can lead to heart disease and stroke [ [37](https://academic.oup.com/cardiovascres/article/85/4/649/294702/Monocytes-in-heart-failure-relationship-to-a)]. Monocytes accumulate in blood vessels and contribute to the development and rupture of atherosclerotic plaques that block blood vessels [ [38](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2862012/), [39](http://atvb.ahajournals.org/content/atvbaha/35/2/272.full.pdf), [40](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2813241/)]. As atherosclerosis progresses, the number of monocytes in the blood tends to rise [ [41](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC1502459/)]. 2) Inflammation in Diabetes A clinical study found no link between diabetes and the number of circulating white blood cells, but monocytes were significantly more numerous in people with complications of diabetes [ [42](https://www.hindawi.com/journals/mi/2012/649083/)]. Some researchers believe that monocytes may be responsible for harmful inflammatory complications in diabetes. Studies have shown that monocytes secrete TNF-alpha, IL-6, and IL-1 in both type 1 and type 2 diabetic patients; these proinflammatory molecules are thought to promote blood vessel (like atherosclerosis) [ [43](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/17112620), [44](http://diabetes.diabetesjournals.org/content/55/3/774), [45](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/8602469?access_num=8602469&link_type=MED&dopt=Abstract), [46](http://www.jimmunol.org/content/jimmunol/183/7/4432.full.pdf), [47](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC1570393/), [48](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/8720604)]. 3) Mortality Rates In a large study of over 4,000 adults in a Swiss hospital, patients with monocytosis experienced more and worse complications than those without. Furthermore, patients with monocytosis had lower survival rates during their hospital stay [ [25](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5515748/)]. In a separate study of elderly Korean men and women, monocytosis was associated with an increased risk of cardiovascular and cancer-related death [ [24](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23228954)]. This connection has not been researched well enough to state for certain that monocytosis can predict mortality rate. However, current research has largely supported the association [ [25](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5515748/), [24](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23228954), [26](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4203415/)]. 4) Heart Attack Recovery After a heart attack, monocytes repair heart damage by removing damaged and dead heart cells. However, animal studies suggest that elevated monocytes are associated with impaired healing after a heart attack [ [49](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2118517/), [50](http://circ.ahajournals.org/content/121/22/2437)]. Factors That Increase Monocytes Several hormones have been associated with increased monocytes. 1) Leptin Human [leptin](https://selfhacked.com/blog/all-about-leptin-its-role-in-chronic-inflammation-cfs-and-weight/) increases monocyte growth and proinflammatory cytokine [ [51](http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0008874999914909)]. Leptin levels correlate with body weight. 2) Menopause There is an increase in blood monocyte number during menopause. Moreover, monocyte counts decline following [estrogen](https://labs.selfdecode.com/blog/estradiol/) replacement therapy [ [52](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/8607941)]. 3) Growth Hormone [Growth hormone](https://labs.selfdecode.com/blog/growth-hormone-101/) injections increase white blood cell counts, including monocytes [ [53](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/10984314)]. 4) Testosterone [Testosterone](https://labs.selfdecode.com/blog/testosterone-will-add/) injections increased the number monocytes, [granulocytes](https://labs.selfdecode.com/blog/granulocytes/), and large lymphocytes in mice [ [54](http://joe.endocrinology-journals.org/content/45/2/313.extract)]. Ways to Decrease Levels Monocytosis is a condition that requires diagnosis and treatment by a medical professional. Talk to your doctor before attempting any strategies to decrease monocyte count. 1) Regular Exercise Regular exercise is anti-inflammatory. In one study, monocytes significantly decreased after a six-week course of moderate-intensity cycling in overweight women who hadn't been regularly exercising. Monocyte counts have also been significantly associated with reduced triglyceride levels, increased [insulin sensitivity](https://health.selfdecode.com/blog/top-tips-for-fixing-insulin-resistance/), and decreased body mass index [ [55](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20145432)]. 2) Weight Loss In obese people, [weight loss](https://health.selfdecode.com/blog/a-comprehensive-list-of-effective-ways-to-lose-weight/) was accompanied by a significant reduction in monocyte and neutrophil counts. The decrease in circulating monocytes correlated with better insulin sensitivity [ [21](http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1550413114001636#)]. 3) Omega-3 Fatty Acids Regular consumption of omega-3 fatty acids—found in oily fish such as mackerel and salmon or [fish oil](https://supplements.selfdecode.com/blog/fish-oil-top-22-science-based-health-benefits-of-fish-oil/) supplements—may protect against atherosclerosis and heart disease [ [56](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2719153/)]. People taking fish oil supplements were less likely to have inflammation in the blood vessel walls caused by monocytes. This effect was not as pronounced in people already taking medication to treat peripheral artery disease [ [57](http://jn.nutrition.org/content/137/12/2769.full.pdf)]. 4) Mediterranean Diet Some research suggests that the Mediterranean diet could reduce inflammation caused by monocytes [ [58](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/19689829), [59](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18196989)]. The Mediterranean diet is comprised of foods such as seeds, nuts, vegetables, fruits, whole grains, and monounsaturated fats from olive oil. 5) Moderate Alcohol Intake Alcohol influences monocyte function. In one study, the monocytes of people who drank a moderate amount of alcohol were less active, even after only a single drink. Monocytes exposed directly to alcohol also had a reduced inflammatory response to proinflammatory compounds [ [60](http://www.jimmunol.org/content/jimmunol/183/2/1320.full.pdf), [61](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2790780/)]. Moderate alcohol consumption, about 1 or 2 drinks per day, is associated with significantly reduced monocyte production of inflammatory cytokines TNF-alpha and IL-1beta. It is also associated with increased production of IL-10, an anti-inflammatory signal[ [62](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/16433741), [61](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2790780/)]. We do not recommend increasing your alcohol intake for the purpose of curtailing inflammation. Talk to your doctor about more appropriate anti-inflammatory strategies. Other Factors That Decrease Monocytes 1) Cortisol and Glucocorticoids As administered by a doctor, a single dose of cortisol decreases monocytes by 90% at 4 to 6 hours after treatment. This reduction persisted for about 24 hours. Subsequently, monocyte levels return to normal 24 to 72 hours after treatment [ [63](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK13780/)]. 2) Estrogen and Progesterone According to one study, estrogen (and possibly also [progesterone](https://supplements.selfdecode.com/blog/top-21-science-based-health-benefits-progesterone-4-drawbacks/)) decreases monocyte count by preventing monocytes from reproducing. This mechanism could explain why cell-mediated immunity appears to drop during pregnancy [ [64](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/12797519)]. 3) Infliximab Infliximab is an immune-suppressing drug prescribed for the treatment of inflammatory diseases such as [Crohn's](https://health.selfdecode.com/blog/ibd-ulcerative-colitis-crohn-genetics-lifestyle-stress-infections/), [ulcerative colitis](https://health.selfdecode.com/blog/ibd-ulcerative-colitis-crohn-genetics-lifestyle-stress-infections/), kills monocytes, which may help reduce inflammation in patients with chronic inflammatory diseases [ [68](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0016508501321042)]. Takeaway The conditions most commonly linked to high monocytes (monocytosis) are chronic infections and inflammation. In turn, having too many monocytes may worsen inflammation and clog your blood vessels. Strategies that may be of interest to people with high monocytes include regular exercise, weight loss, and a Mediterranean-style diet. Learn More
